data.title: Trinity Capital: NAV Growth Continues In Q4
data.description:
Overview

Business Development Companies continue to face headwinds over the last few quarters and many high quality choices have struggled to grow earnings. However, Trinity Capital (TRIN) has revealed itself to be the exception amongst the BDC landscape. TRIN has just reported its Q4 earnings, and I wanted to revisit this BDC to provide some updated insights into its performance and outlook for 2026. While TRIN still faces some similar headwinds as peers, the portfolio strategy has proven to be effective at producing consistent cash flows, supporting dividends, and preserving investor capital. When I previously covered TRIN, I issued a hold rating due to the valuation at the time.

Looking at the performance over the last twelve months, we can see that TRIN's share price has declined by about 3.5%. Despite this decline, I think it's fair to call out that many BDC peers in the sector have seen their share price rapidly erode over the last quarter. Therefore, TRIN remains one of the more resilient choices in the sector. When including all distributions that were paid out to shareholders, the total return jumps up to 10.3% over the same time frame. TRIN now offers investors a starting dividend yield of 13.5%, while now issuing payouts on a monthly basis!

The latest earnings report indicates that net investment income still supports the distributions, but there is certainly some room for improvement. One of the most notable achievements over the last quarter is that TRIN was able to provide some meaningful NAV growth over the last quarter, which indicates that the portfolio continues to generate sufficient income through these challenging market conditions. However, valuation remains tricky because these strengths have caused the BDC to trade at the higher end of its price-to-NAV range. So let's start by taking a look at the portfolio strategy and the highlights of its most recent earnings.

Q4 Earnings

According to the most recent portfolio breakdown, TRIN has total investments at a fair value of $2.4B that are spread across a diverse range of debt securities. Unlike traditional equities, TRIN doesn't rely on the earnings growth of its investments. This is what makes TRIN a great hedge against the uncertainty of the market indices. Instead, TRIN invests in a portfolio of middle-market companies and relies on a borrower's ability to keep up with their required debt maintenance. TRIN's structure is most heavily reliant on loans since they make up most of its investments, but there is some exposure to other income streams. The breakdown by investment type is as follows:

  • Loans: 77.1%
  • Equipment Financings: 13.9%
  • Equity & Warrants: 9%

Expanding on this diversity, the portfolio of investments also spans across different industries. As we can see below, TRIN is most heavily allocated to finance and insurance investments at 15.1% of assets. This is followed by an allocation to medical devices and SaaS investments, which accounts for 10% and 9.2% of assets, respectively. With the selloff of SaaS companies, TRIN has remained resilient since it makes up only a fraction of its portfolio. This is the strength of TRIN's diversity. However, there is a sizeable allocation to different sub-sectors of technology, including AI & automation and green technology investments. If the entire tech industry experiences an extended downturn, this could be a source of risk at some point.

TRIN recently reported its Q4 earnings, and I believe the results were solid. Most notably, net investment income amounted to $0.52 per share, which represents a decline from the prior year's net investment income of $0.58 per share. Interestingly, TRIN saw a rise in its interest and dividend income over the quarter, but the operating expenses substantially increased. Total interest income and dividend income amounted to $77.5M, which was an increase from the prior year's total interest and dividend income of $66.3M. The higher interest income is a clear indication that TRIN's new investments have continued to materialize and are now producing a higher level of income within the portfolio.

However, total operating expenses landed at $43.6M for the quarter. This increase was primarily driven by an uptick in the interest expenses and other debt financing costs, which now total $23.8M. This was an increase from the prior year's interest expenses of $19M. There was also a slight increase in compensation benefits being paid out, which now totaled $14.8M.

One of the weaker aspects of the earnings report was the fact that TRIN faced net realized losses of $33.9M on its investments. However, this doesn't necessarily mean that positions are struggling to grow in value. These losses were attributed to the conversion of two debt positions, which is just the result of some rotations implemented within its portfolio. This was essentially offset by $33.4M in unrealized appreciation from investments during the quarter.

From a balance sheet perspective, there is still some room for improvement. For instance, total cash and equivalents now amounts to $19.1M. While this is an increase from the prior year's balance of $9.6M, this is offset by a rise in liabilities. During the quarter, TRIN added another $198M in secured notes, while the credit facility rose to $373.9M. The shifts over the quarter ultimately led to total liabilities rising to $1.39B, up from $951M from the prior year. As long as this debt eventually leads to higher income, it may not be such an issue at this time.

Valuation & Risk Profile

At the time of my last coverage, TRIN traded at a premium to NAV of 21.4%. Following the latest pullback in its share price, TRIN now trades at a slightly smaller discount to NAV of 12.09%. For reference, TRIN has traded at an average premium to NAV of 7.72% over the last five years. Referring to the red line on the graph below, we can see how TRIN trades at a much higher premium to NAV than peers. However, the valuation can be a bit tricky because a BDC's price to NAV level is usually a direct reflection of the sentiment. If a BDC is perceived as high quality by the market, it can trade at a massive premium to NAV and this makes it difficult to get in at an attractive level.

Despite the decline in its premium to NAV valuation, I think a highlight from the quarter was the rate of capital allocated to new investments. As management is able to allocate capital towards new investments, TRIN's base assets will continue to rise, and the earnings may increase as these new investments begin to materialize throughout the course of the year. During the quarter, TRIN was able to originate $543.1M in total new commitments, including $170.7M allocated to five new portfolio companies, with another $264M allocated to twenty-five existing portfolio companies.

These new investments were offset by exits and repayments of $218.8M during the quarter. Overall, TRIN experienced a positive net increase of $192.1M in portfolio activity for the quarter, ultimately contributing to the positive NAV growth. TRIN's positive NAV growth is a clear indication of the efficiency of the portfolio. TRIN has been able to consistently increase its NAV since Q1. For reference, here are the quarter-end NAV amounts over the last year:

  • Q4 2024: $13.35 per share
  • Q1 2025: $13.05 per share
  • Q2 2025: $13.27 per share
  • Q3 2025: $13.31 per share
  • Q4 2025: $13.42 per share

Despite the NAV growth, there are still some risks that should be considered. These risks are mostly from a macro perspective and will be driven by the direction of interest rates. If we remain in a higher for longer environment, there's always a chance that non-accruals can increase. Thankfully, non-accruals remain relatively low, now totaling 0.7% of fair portfolio value. This represents a slight decline from the non-accruals totaling 0.9% of fair portfolio value at the time of my last coverage.

So therefore, I don't believe TRIN presents any glaring red flags that investors should remain cautious of. Instead, the issues may arise as a result of unfavorable market conditions. If you want exposure to the BDC market, I would actually consider TRIN to be one of the lowest risk opportunities in the market right now. Just as a point of reference, we can see how TRIN is now one of the best performing BDCs over the last year. While the rest of the sector suffers from rising non-accruals, lower earnings, shrinking dividend coverage, and difficulty investing into new opportunities, TRIN has been able to differentiate itself through a strong portfolio strategy and efficient capital allocation.

Despite the tricky valuation, I believe that these are clear signs that it is a great time to accumulate. When interest rates eventually do decline, this will improve the operating spread for TRIN between the cost of its leverage and yield collected from portfolio companies. A healthier cost of debt would also provide some relief for existing portfolio companies, which may lead to higher valuations and lead to net realized gains.

Thin Dividend Coverage

As of the latest declared monthly distribution of $0.17 per share, the current dividend yield sits around 13.5%. It should be noted that TRIN has recently converted its payout frequency to a monthly basis, which is great for investors that depend on the income generated within their portfolio! If we take this new monthly distribution and multiply it by three months, we get an estimated quarterly payout of $0.51 per share. As previously mentioned, net investment income amounted to $0.52 per share for the quarter. While the distribution is still supported by earnings, the base coverage is quite thin at this time.

There is no indication of any spillover income available either, so a scenario where non-accrual rises may threaten the sustainability of payouts. As we've seen over the last quarter, sentiment can change quite rapidly, so I would love to see net investment income stay above the $0.55 range so that there is some excess income that can offset any headwinds. Despite these concerns, the portfolio strength looks great, and the new investments may eventually materialize to higher earnings through 2026. Therefore, I believe that TRIN is still a solid choice for income investors at this time.

Lastly, investors should consider the fact that distributions received from TRIN may not offer tax efficiency. Since the distributions are being supported by interest income received from borrowers, the income would be classified as ordinary dividends, which have the greatest tax burden for investors. Therefore, a position in TRIN would be best utilized within a tax-advantaged account for investors looking to limit their overall tax liability.

Takeaway

In conclusion, I am upgrading my rating on TRIN to a buy at this time. The share price still trades at the higher end of its price-to-NAV range, but it is often very difficult to find an attractive entry on these higher quality BDCs. The portfolio remains resilient, and non-accruals are low, which reinforces the quality of management's underwriting. The earnings saw a slight decline due to higher operating costs, but this shouldn't be an issue as long as the new investment activity eventually materializes into higher net investment income. The distributions are supported by earnings, and the new monthly frequency makes it a great option for investors seeking a reliable stream of income within their portfolio.

data.title: Virtu Financial: A Bet On Volatility, Not On Growth
data.description:
My thesis

Virtu Financial (VIRT) is not an investment for growth; it's an investment for the market's fear and chaos. This company works like a liquidity provider, whose profitability is directly correlated with the VIX index and trading volumes, rather than economic health. In February 2026, the share price fluctuates around the $40 range. While the P/E rate appears low, just 7.7x, compared to the sector's median of around 14x, this reflects the cyclical 2025 peak, rather than a sustainable trend.

Investors need to understand that 2025 was exceptional: annual revenue jumped to $3.63 billion, and adjusted EPS reached $5.73. Though the current dividend yield has shrunk to around 2.4%, which is way lower than the historical 4-5% average, suggesting that the share price is currently not low. The company in 2025 bought back shares for $135 million, though this is more to maintain the price, rather than create new value. This is an instrument for portfolio hedging, not so much an engine for long-term capital accumulation.

Business overview

Virtu Financial works like a financial liquidity provider, whose revenue depends on trading volumes and volatility. The company is making operations in over 235 markets and exchanges in 36 countries, trading over 25,000 different financial instruments. The main source of revenue is the bid-ask spread, and it makes up millions of transactions per day. In 2025 Q4, the company reached an average adjusted net trading income (ANTI) of $9.7 million per day. This directly correlates with the market's activity: when the VIX index is higher, margins expand, and in calmer periods, they pull back. EPS in 2025 reached $5.73, which suggests a significant efficiency compared to the historical average of $3-$4.

The company's activity is divided into two segments: market making and execution services. The market making remains a dominating segment, at the end of 2025, generating around $7.8 million ANTI per day, which makes up around 80% of the whole trading income. This segment is identified with high profitability; the trading segment EBITDA margin in 2025 Q4 reached 72%. The second segment, execution services, works like a more stable revenue flow, servicing institutional clients through algorithmic orders and the ITG platform. This segment in 2025 reached $2.0 million average daily income, growing for the 7th quarter in a row. Even though execution services make up a smaller part, they still cover fixed costs in periods when the market's volatility is low.

Valuation

Virtu Financial shares are currently traded at around $40, with a 7.7x P/E. This is a significant discount compared to a 5 year historical average, which reaches 10.2x. The market currently values VIRT like a stagnant asset, despite the fact that in 2025, adjusted EPS reached $5.73. For comparison, the overall financial sector is usually traded at 12-14x P/E. This low of a valuation for the company shows that investors have doubts if the company will be able to maintain this profitability if the market volatility were to slow down.

The enterprise value to EBITDA ratio is only at 7.4x. This is way lower than the broader capital markets sector median, which is usually over 11x. Such a low ratio looks unusual, considering that in 2025 total revenue grew by 26% and reached $3.63 billion. Also, more importantly, adjusted EBITDA grew 52% in a year to $1.4 billion. Q4 Trading segment EBITDA margins reached 72%, which confirms the business model's ability to generate cash flows without additional costs.

Book value per share currently is $17.14. This makes the price-to-book ratio 2.3x. Even though the ratio is over the sector's average, it's justified because of a very high asset utilization efficiency. P/S is reaching 1.7x, which is lower than most technology-enabled financial companies. Current valuation suggests a clear gap between the growth of fundamental indicators and the contraction of share price multiples.

Comparison

Virtu Financial's valuation shows a big gap between the main competitors and the broader capital markets sector. VIRT shares are traded at an 8.0x forward P/E rate, which is drastically lower than the sector's average, which reaches around the higher teens to twenties. For comparison, exchange operators such as Nasdaq (NDAQ) or Cboe Global Markets (CBOE) are usually valued at an 18-22x range, because of their stable revenues. VIRT's P/B ratio is reaching around 2.1x, while the closest competitors, for example, BGC Group or Charles Schwab, are traded at a 3.7x ratio. The market completely applies a discount for VIRT shares, because their business model is directly linked to the market's volatility and trading volumes, which are very unpredictable, opposite to exchange operators with their subscription and data sales revenues. This valuation gap suggests that investors consider VIRT not a growth, but rather a dividend yield instrument, demanding a high-risk premium for the cyclicality of profits.

Share buybacks and dividends

Virtu Financial sticks to a conservative, fixed dividend policy and pays out $0.24 per share every quarter. This makes up a $0.96 yearly payment, which hasn't changed for a few years. At a current share price of around $40, dividend yield is 2.4%, which is much lower than the historical average of this company, which is 4-5%, though this drop happened, not because of dividend lowering, but because of rapid share price growth, because of successful 2025 results. The most important indicator here is the payout ratio. The company, through 2025, earned $5.73 adjusted EPS, so allocation for dividends is only about 19% of net profit. This suggests that the dividend is very safe, even if the market's volatility in the future decreases.

Throughout 2025 Virtu Financial for share buybacks spent $135.3 million. For this amount, they bought and terminated 3.5 million of their shares. Even though this seems like a solid amount, it only makes up around 4% of the market capitalization. The total number of shares outstanding in the market decreased to 84.9 million units. Also worth noticing is that the management makes purchases opportunistically, so when the share price goes down, the buyback pace increases, though in 2025, when the shares had risen, buyback intensity was moderate. Despite that, regular share reduction mechanically increases the EPS ratio, even if gross profit remains stable.

All together with dividends and share buybacks, the total yield is reaching around 6.5%. This is a solid ratio in the financial sector, though investors have to keep in mind the balance structure. At the end of 2025, the company had $1.13 billion in cash, and long-term debt reached $2.07 billion. Considering that in 2025 adjusted EBITDA reached $1.4 billion, the company has enough flows both for debt servicing and further capital return to shareholders. Current valuation suggests that the market has already priced in the success of 2025, so expecting a further rapid yield growth without higher market chaos, which increases VIRT's revenues, would be naive.

Risks

The biggest risk for the VIRT business model is that in 2025-2026 SEC “Reg NMS” amendments come into effect. From 2025 to May 2026, a mandatory reduction in minimum tick size to $0.005 or even $0.001 for some shares, which directly lowers bid/ask spreads. Since VIRT in 2025 generated $2.44 billion net trading income exactly from these spreads, their contraction means lower revenues for the same amount of trades. This is a structural profitability decrease, which cannot be compensated for by higher turnover alone.

The second risk is the high dependency on the market's volatility, which in 2025 was very high. In Q4, VIRT reached a record EPS of $1.85, when the VIX index was usually over 18. Though historically the VIX average is around 15. If the market stabilises in 2026 and the VIX drops to the 12-13 level, profits may decrease more than 50%, no matter if the company stays efficient. Also, December 2025, received a $2.5 million SEC fine for customer data protection gaps, showing that operational risks remain high, while regulators attention to algorithmic trading is only increasing.

Thesis summary

Virtu Financial started 2026 not like a growth story, but rather like a cyclical market's volatility position. 2025 results were exceptional; revenues grew to $3.63 billion, and adjusted EPS reached a $5.73 rate. Though the current 7-8x P/E ratio is looking more like the market's skepticism on the sustainability of these results, rather than a structural discount. Virtu's profitability directly depends on the trading volumes and VIX index, so without increased market chaos, these profit levels could be hard to replicate.

Even though dividend policy remains conservative, and the payout ratio is only reaching around 19%, the current 2.4% yield suggests that the share is not cheap anymore. Buybacks and capital returns give additional support for the price, though it's more of a support mechanism than a strategy for long-term value creation.

Valuing the risk, upcoming "Reg NMS" changes, and possible market volatility decrease could significantly impact bid-ask differential profitability. So Virtu today works more like a portfolio hedging or tactical cyclical instrument, than a stable long-term capital growth investment. Further returns will depend on the market's anxiety and trading activity levels, rather than economic growth.

data.title: Rates Spark: Inflation Data Next Test For Bullish Euro Rates
data.description:
By Michiel Tukker, Senior European Rates Strategist

Eurozone inflation stable, but also source of risk

Inflation surprises remain a risk to our rates view, both in terms of upside and downside risks. Markets are positioned for lower inflation, with the 2Y inflation swap marking 1.75% now, which is well below the European Central Bank’s target. Nevertheless, only 7bp of ECB easing is priced in for 2026, suggesting the probability of another rate cut is just 30%. This means that markets are content with an undershoot and don’t see the need for the ECB to respond.

If we get lower CPI readings from the major eurozone countries today, then the case for more ECB cuts could quickly build – especially since rates seem keen to test lower the past few weeks. But also in the other direction, we see upside risks. The long end of the curve is still not fully confident that the ECB can keep inflation close to target over the long run. The 10Y inflation swap is still below 2%, even though in pre-quantitative easing times this number was usually around 2.2%, suggesting a 20bp risk premium. In effect, if we start seeing a series of strong inflation data in the coming months, then that could also push the back end up materially.

Oil remains one piece of the inflation puzzle, but more recently the euro exchange rate and gas prices are more important driving forces behind rates. Gas prices jumped higher in January but have since lowered again. In the opposite direction, we had a sharp appreciation of the euro, but this has also broadly reverted since its January peak. That means we’re in quite a balanced position in terms of inflation expectations now. This is also reflected by the fact that both 2Y and 10Y inflation swaps are trading close to their six-month average.

Meanwhile, we see that global rates markets are holding on to their bullish momentum. The AI jitters continue to keep risk sentiment on edge, and private credit concerns don't help either. We still think rates have come down too far, especially when seeing euro equities hitting new records. On the other hand, we don't see much willingness for rates to pop back up again, raising the question of whether investors are becoming more keen to add some safety to their portfolio in the form of euro bonds.

Inflation swaps suggest markets are positioned for an undershooting

Friday’s events and market views

Markets will be watching French, Spanish and German CPI numbers, which will help build expectations for the eurozone aggregate number coming on Tuesday. From the US, we have PPI data, the MNI Chicago PMI, and construction spending figures.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

data.title: Clipper Realty: Cheap Even With Office And Political Overhangs
data.description:
Shares of Clipper Realty (CLPR) have been a poor performer over the past year, losing over a quarter of their value. The loss of a tenant in an office property, and increased concerns about rent regulations have weighed on shares. I last covered shares of Clipper in May 2025 when I rated the stock a “buy,” but this has been a poor call, with shares losing 18% since then and missing out on a 17% market rally. I misread the political risk in NYC, though that appears to be largely priced into shares at this point. With updated financials, now is a good time to revisit CLPR.

In the company’s fourth quarter, Clipper generated $0.04 of funds from operations, which was $0.02 below expectations as revenue declined by 2.6% to $37 million, hampered by lease-up costs, which are temporary. For the full year, the company generated $0.56 of FFO, down from $0.68 in 2024. Adjusted EBITDA was actually flat at $74 million, but rising interest expense has reduced cash flow. The company’s share price has been negatively impacted by revised rental regulations in New York, which generally limit lease rate inflation to 2.75% and make it harder to convert units out of rent stabilization.

Residential results were solid, but political risk looms

In its residential division, new leases were up 13%, with renewal rates also up a strong 7%. As a result, revenues grew by $2.7 million to $31 million, primarily from increased rents at stabilized properties. Additionally, its Prospect House property in Brooklyn is successfully leasing up, with occupancy now up to 66% and most of its unregulated units yet to be leased. We should see a substantial increase from the $1.5 million of revenue generated in Q4 from this property as it completes its lease-up and gets to a run-rate footing, likely around midyear 2026.

The election of Mayor Zohran Mamdani in New York has added further uncertainty to the space, given his focus on this issue. In particular, he campaigned on freezing rent and is taking steps to do that via appointments to the Rent Guidelines Board. Mamdani has also pushed to increase housing construction, meeting with President Trump on this issue. At some point, these competing policy priorities may come into conflict, as rent restrictions may reduce the attractiveness of developing new apartments. Regardless, the overall policy stance is not particularly friendly towards residential landlords like Clipper.

Its Flatbush Garden complex is its primary rent-regulated building. The property generated $13.2 million of revenue, up about 7% from last year, and its leased rate was strong at 98.2%. It was able to push leased rates to $32/square foot from $30 last year. There is a risk that revenue growth could slow materially on this property if Mamdani’s policy goals are achieved. Its Tribeca property, which has less rent regulation exposure, saw revenue jump nearly 10% to $11.7 million, and occupancy is excellent at 99.4%. On this property, CLPR charges $89/sqft, and that gap speaks to how beneficial having market-oriented apartment exposure is relative to rent-regulated units.

I think it is also important to note that while the national residential rental market is battling negative rent, New York City has been a significant outperformer, aided by less supply post-COVID than in Sun Belt markets. Rents are still rising, up 2% from last year. With new construction levels fairly muted, any supply-side effort is unlikely to hit the market before 2028/2029. As such, in non-rent-regulated units, I expected continued positive rental inflation. Outcomes in rent-regulated units are much harder to predict and have meaningful political uncertainty associated with them.

Tenant loss hampers office results

Its commercial unit has faced more difficulties as the city government exited its 250 Livingston Lease, and 141 Livingston faced claims from creditors. Revenue was down $3.6 million from last year to $6.2 million, entirely due to developments on 250 Livingston. Because it lost the city government lease, revenue from 250 Livingston declined by over 80% to $600k, coming from 36 residential units in the building. I previously wrote that finding a tenant in this office market would be very difficult and assumed no new tenant.

Recognizing this, CLPR has stopped making interest and tax payments on this property, essentially defaulting on its mortgage. This loan, like the majority on CLPR’s properties, is nonrecourse. That means Clipper can walk away from an underwater building like 250 Livingston, and lenders have no claim on the rest of its assets. Rather than fund losses out of cash flow from other buildings, management has determined the building to be worth less than the outstanding debt on it. Unless lenders materially modify the mortgage, it is likely to be foreclosed.

Separately, the lender on 141 Livingston had alleged CLPR breached covenants by failing to maintain a $100 million net worth. CLPR was able to resolve all claims by posting a $10 million letter of credit and incurring $2.6 million of settlement expenses. Importantly, this allows the 5-year lease with its main tenant, the city government, to go through.

The balance sheet offers flexibility

Turning to its balance sheet, Clipper has $1.3 billion of debt, and it also has $31 million of cash. Net debt was flat over the past year. As noted above, CLPR primarily borrows at the property level. This provides flexibility as property fundamentals change. For instance, it has $125 million against its 250 Livingston property, which we may see exit its balance sheet. Its two primary mortgages are the $360 million against Tribeca House, one of its best-performing assets, and its $329 million against Flatbush Gardens.

Importantly, the company has no near-term maturities. However, many of these loans carry low-rate mortgages. Most notably, its Flatbush Gardens loan is at 3.125%. This does not mature until 2032, but we are likely to see a materially higher interest rate given both the absolute level of rates and negativity around rent-regulated exposure, and this is likely to add several million in run-rate annual interest expense.

Dividend should be secure in 2026

Shares offer an 11% dividend yield. During 2025, Clipper generated $23 million of operating cash flow, down from $32 million last year, though this still covered its $18.5 million of dividend payments. As a general rule, whenever I see a double-digit dividend yield, that is an immediate warning sign that markets believe the payout may not be sustained. The company did fully cover its dividend in 2025; however, this included a partial-year contribution from 250 Livingston. On the other hand, Prospect House is still leasing up. In Q4, CLPR did not cover its dividend. Once we get to run-rate on Prospect House and exit 250 Livingston, we should see ~$0.06 of benefits. At $0.10 per quarter, CLPR barely covers its dividend.

Now, given the dynamics discussed above, we should see ongoing rental inflation at all non-regulated units, but there is considerable uncertainty about the path forward on H2 rent-regulated units and whether a freeze could be implemented. Given the fact operating expenses do rise over time, a rent freeze could erode cash flow. At this time, I expect a deceleration in rent inflation, but I do not view 0% as the base case either.

Depending on the outcome here and the speed of the Prospect House lease-up, I expect $0.38-$0.44 of FFO, which protects the dividend this year. That said, over the medium term, Clipper’s interest expense is likely to rise as it refinances maturities, though this is not a pressing issue until the 2028-2032 period. Still, by 2032, interest expense could be $15 million higher, or over $0.30/share.

Of course, much depends on the rate environment, which is completely unknowable several years from now. This thought is where the medium-term trajectory of rents becomes essential. With 2.5+% rent inflation, CLPR can grow the topline sufficiently to absorb higher rates, but at 1.5% or lower, interest expense will begin to squeeze the dividend. Shares are yielding 11%, in part reflecting this medium-term risk.

I remain a "buy," given depressed valuation

I do not expect a change to dividend policy in 2026 or likely even 2027, but there is uncertainty beyond then. That said, CLPR’s balance sheet structure of nonrecourse loans gives it a tremendous amount of flexibility and truncates downside on any single property. After the decline in shares and at sub-9x 2026 FFO, it seems to me that all the political risk is being priced in already, and fundamentals outside rent-regulated units are still quite solid in the NYC area.

As such, I remain a "buy." Given the increased political overhang from the NYC mayoral election (a risk I admittedly took too lightly last May, leading to my erroneous buy rating), I no longer think shares can get to $5, but I view 10x FFO as attainable as we see Prospect House results improve and AFFO cover the dividend. With upside towards $4.00 plus its 11% yield, I view CLPR as having attractive upside, though the political environment remains a risk.

data.title: Why Gold's Pullback Is A Setup, Not A Setback
data.description:
Discover why we believe gold drawdowns are normal, why the bull market has room to run, and the case for including real assets in every portfolio.

A new regime for real assets may be underway, driven by surging electricity demand, AI infrastructure buildout, and shifting monetary dynamics. Against this backdrop, we examine gold’s role in the cycle, why periodic corrections are historically normal for the metal, silver’s potential, and how diversified real asset exposure through the VanEck Real Assets ETF (RAAX) can help position portfolios for the debasement era.

The Gold Rally Has More Upside

Looking at the current gold environment through the lens of the two previous major bull markets provides helpful context: the 1976–1980 cycle (which produced roughly 500% cumulative returns) and the 2001–2011 cycle (roughly 600% cumulative returns). The current cycle, which began in 2022, has generated approximately 200% so far. Importantly, both prior bull markets experienced five corrections of 10% or more along the way. The recent pullback represents the second such correction in this cycle and falls well within historical norms.

  • Prior gold bull markets produced 500–600% cumulative returns; the current cycle has delivered roughly 200%.
  • Both the 1970s and 2000s bull markets experienced five corrections of 10% or more.
  • The recent pullback is the second such correction in this cycle and is consistent with historical patterns.

By Historical Standards, We View Gold’s Bull Market is in its Infancy

Gold – Cumulative Total Return

The RAAX ETF: A One-Stop Real Asset Allocation

The VanEck Real Assets ETF primarily allocates to exchange-traded products that provide exposure to real assets. Over the past five years, a portfolio of 55% stocks, 35% bonds, and 10% RAAX delivered a 47.5% cumulative return with an annualized standard deviation of 10.3%—outperforming a traditional 60/40 portfolio with virtually identical risk.

RAAX Average Annual Total Returns as of 12/31/2025* (%)
