data.title: Nayax: Market Sentiments Cool Execution Upside (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
Despite the recent correction, Nayax (NYAX) is up ~15% on average on my three buy ratings. Going into Q4, I think the valuation reality has changed. Multiple compression across the payments space has lowered the ceiling for fintech stocks. The market remains skittish, with AI concerns lowering the tolerance for long-duration growth stories. While operationally Nayax has never been stronger and the company’s growth profile deserves a premium, I think a $52-$54 entry point makes this a high-risk bet with a limited margin of safety in the current market environment. I am therefore downgrading my rating to hold.

Things to watch in Q4: Mix Shift and Enterprise Acceleration

Nayax is scheduled to release earnings on March 9, 2026. To frame long-term expectations from this report, we must look at trends in unit economics in the company’s core verticals.

Nayax is currently undergoing a mix-shift towards high-yield verticals, which offer a lift to processing revenue without a linear increase in device count. In 3Q25, the Total Transaction Value (or, TTV) increased 34.6%, while the number of managed devices grew only by 16.8%. This is similar to the ratio observed in 2Q but the earnings before that indicate the ratio was often close to 1:1.

A look at the average ticket sizes below reveals that this growth ratio could be quite a lot higher than 2:1.

Category Average Ticket Size
EV charge on AC $3-$4
EV charge on DC $18
Vending machine $2.24

AC charging is the dominant category of installations globally, but DC installations are growing at a faster clip. The most critical factor is charging time. AC chargers require a vehicle’s onboard converter to change from AC to DC. In contrast, DC chargers can convert power inside the station and send it directly to the EV battery. This can juice an EV to 80% in under an hour compared to about 4-10 hours for AC.

The second factor is range anxiety. While AC chargers are installed in residential and workplace settings, DC chargers serve en route locations such as highways and urban hubs, where faster charging directly addresses range anxiety. In the US, the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure program had allocated $5 billion to build DC charging networks along highways. But these didn’t exactly pan out amidst opposition from the federal government last year. Regardless, I think the trendline remains clear. Just a few days ago, Nayax signed an agreement with Tritium, a DC charging manufacturer, to integrate its payment hardware across a charging network spanning over 50 countries.

So we're seeing a high demand. Q4 is always -- is a big enterprise, and we have a very, very good visibility to end this quarter with the expectation that we set to the market. - Yair Nechmad, CEO of Nayax at 3Q25 Results

In Q3, management also mentioned an acceleration in enterprise sales. The impact of enterprise mix on margins was not explicitly mentioned. However, they appeared confident in staying in the higher end of 30%-35% hardware margins, which I think implies that enterprise sales are consistent with and not dilutive to those higher margins. A combination of these factors and the fact that companies tend to sandbag expectations leads me to believe that the company will likely continue to affirm its 2028 targets in its last quarter earnings.

Valuation

With the company’s 2028 targets still intact, not much has changed in terms of my target range. But I also think the edge in valuation disappears if the market perceives the discount rate as being structurally higher to account for AI risks. Unfortunately, this isn’t a company issue but a macro issue, which makes the stock behave like a long-duration asset. Because of this factor, I thought the stock could keep drifting in and out of the first two regimes below.

Regime Fair Value Interpretation
Execution + normal discount rate ~$66–$78 Moderate upside
Execution + high discount rate ~$46 - $50 Fairly valued
Execution miss <$40 Real downside

If the execution remains on course and discount rates normalize, there is meaningful upside. If the discount rate remains high, the equity drifts sideways. Only under conditions of weak execution does the thesis break decisively. So a market-perform or hold rating makes sense for a macro call on a fundamentally improving business.

Conclusion

Operationally, Nayax is at its strongest point, and the company's growth levers are structurally sound. For the investor who bought at a $44 price point, the stock has offered a decent return in a short period of time. This is especially true if you managed to sell at the $60 highs seen last month.

I continue to like the company. I am just a little less enthusiastic about the entry point where the broader market is compressing multiples and is demanding faster resolution of growth stories. A pullback to the mid-40s without a clear operational reason would provide a higher margin of safety to accumulate. Otherwise, I expect the stock to move in line with market sentiments in the near term.

data.title: Shake Shack: Tremendous Buy As January Comps Accelerate
data.description:
In my eyes, 2026 is hardly a stock market built for passive investing. The S&P 500 appears to be stuck at levels just shy of 7,000 as the market struggles to find direction. The tech stocks that have powered much of the market's dizzying ascent over the past few years are mostly in deep correction territory. Meanwhile, consumer-facing companies, including those in the restaurant sector, are also facing persistent challenges as investors worry about inflationary pressures plus macro headwinds on restaurant traffic.

But against this backdrop, Shake Shack (SHAK) remains one of my favored plays in the restaurant space. The elevated burger chain has continued to deliver healthy comps that compare well against other "fast casual" restaurant chains. Despite this, shares remain down ~10% over the past year, still creating a well-timed buying opportunity.

I last wrote a buy opinion on Shake Shack in October, when the stock was trading at ~$90 per share. Since then, Shake Shack has enjoyed a meaningful uptrend even as the rest of the stock market has floundered. Amid healthy guidance looking ahead to FY26, amid the company noting that sales trends have improved materially in the early part of Q1, I'm reiterating my buy rating on Shake Shack.

Well positioned for success in 2026, with reasonable valuation against a robust outlook

In my view, there are two core catalysts that Shake Shack can count as tailwinds in the upcoming year. The first is that the company continues to expand into new international markets via licensing deals. In Q4, the company grew its sales from licensed locations by 26% y/y to $232.7 million, which is 38% of the company's systemwide sales of $618 million. Licensing fee revenue (Shake Shack's cut of these sales) grew 28% y/y to $15.3 million, still a small 4% slice of overall sales - and yet, it's also a "free", high-margin revenue stream that allows Shake Shack to substantially expand its brand presence with low capital needs and low risk.

Over the past few months alone, the company has opened locations in Hong Kong, Philippines, Shanghai, Canada, Israel, Korea, and others - as shown above. The company expects to open 40-45 new licensed locations in FY26, representing meaningful growth from its current base of 286 licensed stores. This stacks on top of 55-60 planned company-owned and operated locations, marking 2026 as a meaningful year for Shake Shack's brand expansion: both in the U.S. and overseas.

The other core catalyst for investors to keep in mind is the fact that within the company's owned and operated portfolio, Shake Shack is getting the hang of more efficient operations. Whereas many restaurant chains are getting bogged down by higher labor costs, Shake Shack has overhauled its labor model to reduce labor costs (as a percentage of revenue), helping to offset the impacts of beef price inflation.

This has allowed the company to keep growing adjusted EBITDA at a double-digit pace, even as its new restaurant openings are just at the point of maturing.

Despite its many growth catalysts, Shake Shack continues to trade at very reasonable valuations. At current share prices near $99, Shake Shack commands a market cap of $4.21 billion. Netting off the $360.1 million of cash and $247.7 million of debt on Shake Shack's most recent balance sheet, the company's resulting enterprise value is $4.10 billion.

For FY26, Shake Shack is guiding to $1.60-$1.70 billion of revenue, or 14% midpoint revenue growth, with 55-60 company-owned openings stacking on top of low single-digit same-shack sales (comp sales) growth, both contributing to double-digit top line expansion. The company is also expecting restaurant-level margins of 23.0-23.5%, representing up to one point of full-year expansion versus a 22.6% margin in FY25. Adjusted EBITDA, at a midpoint of $241 million, represents a 14.6% margin (+10bps y/y) and 15% y/y growth.

Shake Shack's valuation is positioned at 17.0x EV/FY26 adjusted EBITDA. While not exactly a value stock, we note that the company sits on the lower end of the spectrum versus true "fast casual" peers like Chipotle and CAVA (CAVA), despite the fact that Shake Shack's comp sales are trending stronger.

Stay long here: in my view, Shake Shack's post-earnings momentum is well positioned to continue.

Q4 recap

Let's now go through Shake Shack's latest quarterly results in greater detail. The Q4 earnings summary is shown below:

Shake Shack's revenue grew 22% y/y to $400.5 million, which accelerated meaningfully versus 16% y/y growth in Q3. The core driver of acceleration was the addition of 15 new company-owned Shacks in Q4, as well as 17 net-new licensed locations. As previously mentioned, though licensing revenue is still a small ~4% slice of overall revenue, the 28% y/y growth rate here (plus the plan to grow licensed locations by another ~16% in FY26) makes this an incredibly high-margin growth lever for the company.

Of course, the most important metric for us to watch here is same-shack sales growth (which other restaurants refer to as "same restaurant sales" or "comp sales" and measures revenue growth from existing locations, without including the contribution of newly opened locations).

The good news is that same-shack sales continued on a recent positive trend, up 2.1% y/y with 160bps of price increases and a favorable menu mix further buoyed by 50bps of y/y traffic increase. This is the company's second consecutive quarter of positive traffic, after y/y declines earlier in the year.

The bad news is that comps decelerated from ~5% growth in Q3. The major headwind here remains the company's core New York City market, where same-shack sales declined -2% y/y. That said, the company noted adverse weather impacts as driving declines.

We note as well that deceleration is more the rule rather than the exception in the industry. Burger King (BK), arguably the company's largest pure-play competitor, though leaning in the fast food space instead of "fast casual," saw comps decelerate to 5.8%, from 6.4% in Q3.

Meanwhile, Mediterranean chain CAVA barely grew comps at all, decelerating 140bps sequentially to 0.5%.

Overall, we are beginning to see the market make an apparent shift toward promotion-oriented fast food brands. McDonald's (MCD) had the most successful Q4 of most restaurant chains, with U.S. comps accelerating to 6.8% in Q4.

That said, we do think Shake Shack, especially with its chef-driven roots and higher quality, maintains a clear distinction versus fast food burgers. We're also encouraged by the fact that Shake Shack noted January comps improved to over 4%, indicating that Q1 same-shack sales may be positioned to recover back to Q3 levels. Per CEO Robert Lynch's remarks on the Q4 earnings call:

Finally, I would like to give some color on our strong start to the year. January same-Shack sales grew 4.3% year-over-year. Despite meaningful weather headwinds in January, we've nevertheless generated solid sales growth, fueled by continued traction in our in-app value platform, increased hours of operations in our Shacks and the launch of compelling culinary innovation.

Our start to the year, coupled with the leadership team that we now have in place, gives me unwavering confidence that our plan is working."

Meanwhile, Shake Shack's adjusted EBITDA margins remained roughly flat y/y at 14.0%, with adjusted EBITDA rising 20% y/y to $56.1 million.

The company is still facing headwinds from higher food costs, particularly in beef. On top of this, a rising mix of Shake Shack's sales are via delivery platforms, increasing commission payments. However, the company's labor model, plus its gradual tilting toward smaller formats (which are both cheaper to run on an ongoing basis and cost $2 million to build, a 20% y/y reduction in startup costs), have helped the company to offset the impacts of inflation.

Risks and key takeaways

Of course, there are risks here that we need to keep in mind. As previously mentioned, McDonald's has been continuing to take more market share with positive U.S. comps in the second half of 2025, reflecting a consumer that is increasingly tilting to promotional deals. Though Shake Shack and McDonald's sit in different dining categories, we note that Shake Shack may feel more pressure to drive more promotions in order to appeal to a cash-strapped consumer. This is stacked on top of the risk of rising beef prices, which the company expects to continue inflating at a high single digit pace in 2026 (partially offset by lower paper and packaging costs).

That said, I see more positives than risks in this stock, especially at a lower valuation multiple than most fast-casual peers and the strong signal from re-accelerating January same-shack sales. Stay long here.

data.title: ExlService Price Down, But I Still Rate It A Strong Buy
data.description:
Investment thesis

The share price of ExlService Holdings, Inc. (EXLS) has fallen quite a bit in recent weeks. What has dragged it down? Is it a permanent problem that demands a Sell rating? Or is it a temporary blip that will turn into a rebound?

In the article, we explore potential reasons for the decline, including its latest earnings, investor expectations, a Seeking Alpha/Quant warning, valuation, and the AI slump.

I conclude it is still a strong buy, despite the slump.

ExlService’s tumbling share price

In the past year, the share price has drifted down, but on February 3, 2026, it took a serious dive, losing 18.68% in a single session. This one-year chart provides an overview of the decline and fall:

Since then, the price has continued to slump. Between January 26, 2026, and the close on February 25, the price fell from $43.19 to $28.67, a drop of 33.62% (although the price began moving up on February 26).

What caused the slump?

ExlService’s latest earnings

In its Q4-2025 and year-end results, the company reported growth on several key metrics:

  • Q4 revenue increased 12.7%, year-over-year to $542.6 million. For the full year, revenue increased 13.5% to $2.09 billion.
  • For the year, net income increased to $251.0 million from $198.2 million in 2024.
  • Basic EPS grew from $1.22 in 2024 to $1.56 in 2025; on a diluted basis, EPS increased from $1.21 to $1.54.

This 5-year chart of revenue, net income, and EPS shows the company has maintained its growth profile:

This is an exemplary chart, with revenue, net income, and EPS not only rising, but rising steadily. Some investors pay a premium for a stock that behaves in such a predictable way, not that further increases will necessarily occur.

However, past performance is one of the few available tools by which we can assess a company’s future performance. Based on this history, I would argue ExlService has an excellent management team that knows how to profitably grow a company.

Therefore, it seems unlikely past performance chased away investors. The chart and history also suggest this is a Buy, not a Sell, stock.

Expectations

Investors also become bearish when they have dim expectations for future performance.

But that likely is not the case here. In the Q4 earnings report, CEO Rohit Kapoor said, “EXL’s recognized industry expertise and leadership in embedding AI in our clients’ businesses are resonating strongly with the market and fueling our growth with new and existing clients. Our investments in building innovative data and AI services and solutions, growing our partner ecosystem, and cultivating AI-native talent are driving our growth momentum and creating differentiated outcomes for our clients.”

Looking further ahead, the Wall Street analysts see double-digit earnings increases for 2026 and beyond:

The analysts have pulled back their estimates for this year and next year since the latest earnings were published. Previously they expected:

  • 2026: 16.15%
  • 2027: 14.42%
  • 2028: 13.77%

Even with the analysts' more cautious outlook, it seems unlikely shareholders would have sold their stock because of low expectations.

Valuation

ExlService receives above average valuation scores when compared with peers in the Industrials sector:

Even on a five-year basis, ExlService outperforms the sector in valuation.

The Seeking Alpha system finds it undervalued on all major ratios; the price multiples and PEG ratios are all below figures for Industrials sector medians. As noted above, it is somewhat overvalued when compared with Genpact and Maximus.

However, it is generally pricier than competitors Genpact Limited (G) and Maximus, Inc. (MMS), as shown in this table:

Could valuation be a factor steering investors away? It is possible some investors may have bought Genpact and Maximus instead, but overall it seems unlikely to have contributed much to the slump.

The warning

There is a red banner from the Quant system: “Warning: EXLS is at high risk of performing badly.” To that, it added the Quant system gives it a Sell rating.

The Quant system explained its reasons, “ExlService Holdings, Inc. has characteristics that have been historically associated with poor future stock performance. EXLS has decelerating momentum and declining growth when compared to other Industrials stocks, to the point that it gets a Sell rating from our Quant rating system.”

Specifically, it is concerned about slowing momentum and declining growth—when compared to other Industrials stocks.

Momentum is obviously a reflection of price movements, and for some time now, the movement has been down. But, if I am right in arguing the price will eventually catch up to earnings, momentum will reverse. Again, we do not know when.

The second warning is for declining growth when compared with other Industrials stocks. But it takes only a quick look at other Seeking Alpha data to see that is not the case. On a current basis, EXLS beats the sector medians on all the metrics shown here and on others not shown:

On a five-year basis, it does lag the sector by most metrics shown here. Still, a scan shows us ExlService delivered double-digit growth across all these metrics, so while it may have lagged, its growth has been substantial.

While I’m not sure when the banner first appeared, it was likely on Monday, February 9, when the Quant system cut its rating from Hold to Sell.

The price slump began before the warning and Sell rating were issued, and the price has changed only modestly since they came out. And while Seeking Alpha has a wide reach, it is not read by all investors. As a result, we can assume the warning has had little to do with falling prices.

Institutional investors

It is possible the decline may have something to do with institutional investors. As the following Seeking Alpha table shows, the professionals own nearly 97% of outstanding shares:

Nasdaq reported two of the biggest institutional funds, BlackRock, Inc. and Vanguard Group Inc. trimmed their holdings in Q4-2025. BlackRock reduced its holding by 5.68% and Vanguard by 2.49%.

Could they or other institutional investors have started cutting their holdings again in late January? It is possible, and somewhat likely, they did it in connection with the AI selloff. Or, since they move such large volumes, perhaps they started the AI slump.

That idea receives backing from the trading volumes. Over the past three months, the average volume has been about 1.5 million shares per day, but over the eight business days following February 2, six of those days had a volume of more than 3.5 million shares. One day had slightly over 3.0 million shares, and the eighth reached 2.9 million shares.

If the institutional investors are selling, it does not necessarily mean fund managers are losing faith in ExlService. These managers buy and sell for many reasons, and not all of them have to do with a firm’s prospects.

Such a large increase in volume suggests institutions were making trades; no other category of owners is likely to move the market so much.

The AI slump

In late January and early February, many prominent AI stocks, including those of Nvidia Corporation (NVDA), experienced sharp pullbacks. This is a one-month chart of Nvidia’s share price:

For a broader perspective on the AI slump, this is a one-month chart of Global X Artificial Intelligence & Technology ETF (AIQ):

Compare that with a one-month chart for ExlService:

The two charts are broadly similar, although ExlService fell farther than AIQ. Why? A report from Anthony Lee of StockStory points to bad news from Gartner, Inc. (IT) on February 3.

Lee wrote, “A number of stocks fell in the morning session after disappointing fourth-quarter results from industry bellwether Gartner sparked widespread concerns about a slowdown in the sector.”

He went on to say, “The research and advisory firm reported that revenue in its Consulting segment fell 12.8%. This weak performance from a major industry player appeared to validate broader market fears about the health of the IT services and consulting industry.”

That story came out on the day ExlService fell 18.68%.

At about the same time, ExlService and several of its peers/competitors dropped as well. This one-year chart of Data Processing & Outsourced Services stocks compares ExlService with Genpact, Maximus, and Verra Mobility Corporation (VRRM):

Each of these stocks suffered price setbacks similar to that of MMS, although the inclusion of all four on one chart seems to dampen the dip for the other three. In particular, Verra, which appears unaffected on the chart, fell by more than a fifth, 21.50%, between January 9 and February 13.

Based on similarities between ExlService share prices and others in the AI sector, it seems likely the AI slump played a significant role in pulling down the price of not only ExlService but also those of its peers.

Is it a buy or a sell?

First, the fundamentals are strong, with the company delivering strong, steady growth over the past five years. In addition, the prospects for the next three years are strong, in the opinion of Wall Street analysts. They expect robust, double-digit earnings growth. And at those growth rates, ExlService should be known as an attractive compounder.

As for the slumping price, I expect it to recover, but do not know when (although it did reverse on February 26). What I do know is that there is a growing gap between the share price and earnings:

Gaps such as this create opportunities for investors, especially value investors, because the share price likely will follow earnings, eventually. This will mean strong capital gains for existing shareholders when (or perhaps if) it happens.

In a previous article, ExlService: A Bond Substitute For Bold Income Investors, on December 16, 2025, I gave the company a Strong Buy based on its consistent growth, and the strength of its offerings in AI and data-driven services. I am maintaining that rating, and see no reason to change my one-year target price of $47.79.

Risk factors

While the price has fallen significantly, it could drop even further. As we saw, it is expensive when compared with its peers, and it is quite possible buyers won’t outnumber sellers until there is P/E parity with Genpact and Maximus.

The Quant system may be correct, and I may be wrong about the significance of the warnings. If that is the case, expect the ExlService price to drop even more in coming weeks or even quarters.

The company’s share price can be shaken by news, as was the case with Gartner’s disappointing earnings results. In this case, I suspect investors overreacted to the news, but they always have the last word.

As an AI integrator, it faces many unknowns, both for its own operations and in what it does for its clients. Any failures could lead to reputational and financial harm.

Conclusion

The share price of ExlService Holdings has both wandered down and plunged for several weeks, apparently because of the AI slump and holding reductions by institutional investors. It further appears its fundamentals and investor expectations have not been factors.

The AI slump and institutional selloffs are likely transitory, and prices should rebound at some point. The fundamentals are robust, and expectations are high based on future EPS estimates.

Finally, the widening gap between the fundamentals and share price suggests an opportunity to buy a quality stock at an undervalued price.

data.title: All Things Considered, The Outlook Is Getting Brighter
data.description:
Here's a selection of charts that I'm paying special attention to these days. If there's a theme emerging from these snapshots of the economy and financial markets, it's a generally upbeat one, featuring continued low inflation, moderate and improving growth, and a gradual improvement in the fiscal outlook.

Chart #1

Chart #1 shows the 6- and 12-month growth rate of private sector jobs - the ones that really count. From a long-term perspective, it looks like the economy is growing at an unusually slow pace - barely a crawl. But considering the massive deportations of illegals and the virtual closure of our borders, it's not surprising.

Some will argue that this shows an economy hovering on the brink of "stall speed," but I think that's an analogy that doesn't really apply to an economy. Economies have a strong tendency to grow if they are not burdened by abrupt and unforeseen changes in monetary and fiscal policy.

Meanwhile, it is comforting to see that new claims for unemployment show absolutely no sign of any fundamental deterioration in the outlook for business profits. Firings are low and stable. The worst that can be said about jobs is that there aren't many new jobs being created. But that could be improving.

Chart #2

Chart #2 shows the monthly change in private sector jobs, which appears to have picked up in the past month. It's too early to claim victory after just one month of improvement, but some of the following charts also show recent improvement.

Chart #3

Chart #3 shows the results of a monthly survey of purchasing managers. It has shown pretty lackluster levels for the past several years, followed by an exceptionally strong January report.

This could be the first sign of a long-expected surge in the outlook for business manufacturing activity. Historically, readings below 47 have frequently coincided with recessionary conditions. Readings north of 50 almost always occur during periods of decent economic growth. If the recent report is not reversed, then we could be on the verge of a very welcome growth spurt.

Chart #4

Chart #4 shows the level of the federal government workforce. The past year has been dominated by an astonishing 11% decline in the federal workforce - the by-product of Trump's aggressive attack on the Deep State, in particular the Dept. of Education.

As the chart also shows, the federal workforce today is as small as it has been since 1966! There are now 324K fewer regulators of the economy. A small government workforce equates to a significant reduction in regulatory burdens, which are typically a cost that most businesses would be happy to avoid.

This frees up resources for productive activity, and this is an unalloyed good thing. No one came close to predicting that the federal government workforce would ever decline by as much as it has in the past year. Note that the spikes in the data that occur every 10 years correspond to the temporary hiring of people needed to conduct the census.

Chart #5

Chart #5 shows the year-over-year change in the Consumer Price Index, compared to a version of the CPI that excludes shelter costs (which make up about ⅓ of the CPI). The gap between the two that shows up in the past several years is the direct result of an overestimation by the BLS of shelter costs. That problem is now behind us, and we are left with inflation that is only moderately above 2%.

Chart #6

Chart #6 focuses on shelter costs (which are called Owner's Equivalent Rent). This is what you would be paying if you had to rent the house you live in, and it is something that the BLS manufactures inside its computers, since nowhere does there exist such a thing in the real world.

Here we see that in the past month and past 3 months, the annualized change in this measure of shelter costs has fallen back - finally - to what it has tended to average in normal times. That explains why the gap between the two lines in Chart #5 has disappeared.

Chart #7

Chart #7 has been featured regularly on this blog for the past several years. It is designed to show that the BLS's calculation of shelter costs (OER) is highly correlated to the year-over-year change in housing prices (blue line) from 18 months prior.

It took longer for OER to fall (given the prior decline in housing price inflation) than I thought, but the two lines are now back in sync at a level that is consistent with 2% overall inflation.

I note further that national home prices rose only 1.2% last year, and, adjusted for inflation, they are 2.2% below their mid-2022 peak. Housing prices are thus quite likely to exert downward pressure on inflation in the months to come.

Chart #8

Chart #8 shows the year-over-year growth rate of the all-important M2 measure of the money supply. M2 rose on average by about 6% per year from 1995 through 2019, a period during which the CPI rose by 2% or less per year.

More recently, M2 growth in the year ending January '26 was a mere 3.6%. In normal, pre-Covid times, most economists would predict that 3.6% M2 growth would lead to a slowdown in economic growth and a decline in inflation. Yet today the chatter is all about whether inflation is going to rise. This could be one of those times when the market is caught looking in the wrong direction.

Chart #9

Chart #9 shows what I consider to be a good measure of money demand: M2 divided by nominal GDP. This effectively measures how much of our annual income we like to hold in the form of readily spendable money (currency, checking accounts, retail money market funds, etc.).

Money demand today is pretty much the same as it was prior to COVID. The Covid years were characterized initially by a gigantic increase in the demand for money, which was then followed by a return or "normal" levels. My interpretation of all this is that monetary conditions are just about right: money supply is matched by money demand, and that equates to the absence of monetary imbalances that might fuel higher inflation.

Chart #10

Chart #10 compares the strength or weakness of the dollar (a rising blue line equates to a weaker dollar, while a declining blue line equates to a stronger dollar) with the inflation-adjusted level of a basket of basic commodity prices. Note the very strong correlation of these two variables over time - except for the period following the Covid crisis, when supply chains were disrupted but the consumers wanted to ramp up their spending.

Commodity prices back then were much stronger than the strength of the dollar would have predicted, and they helped fuel rising inflation. Recently, however, the two variables have come back into line with each other. Commodity prices are no longer "too strong," while the dollar is still reasonably strong itself.

Conclusion: Commodity prices are not a source of inflation these days. Need I add that gasoline prices today are very close to their 20-year average ($2.88/gallon), and that they have fallen almost 40% from their 2022 high? Moreover, crude oil prices today are actually almost 10% lower than their 20-year average.

Chart #11

Chart #11 shows the level of real GDP growth as it compares to two different trend lines (it's important to note the use of a log scale on the y-axis, which makes it easy to see growth trends). GDP rose by about 3.1% per year from 1966 through 2007, but since 2010 it has managed to grow by only a little more than 2.3% per year.

Growth may be picking up of late, as noted in the comments above, but even if it does, the economy is still a lot less dynamic than it has been during most of our lifetimes.

I think the "disappointing" growth of GDP since 2010 is due to several factors: 1) the $16 trillion the world spent on futile attempts to prevent global warming, 2) a huge increase in US transfer payments, and 3) a significant increase in regulatory burdens. All of which, I'm pleased to note, are in the process of reversing!

Chart #12

Chart #12 shows the level of federal government spending and revenues over the past 36 years. The difference between the two lines is, of course, the federal deficit, which is currently running at about $1.7 trillion per year.

Note also the huge surge in federal spending triggered by the Covid crisis - that consisted of approximately $6 trillion in transfer payments, which were effectively monetized by the Fed. It was all a nightmare, but it's fading rapidly. Note that spending has not reached new highs since 2022, and it has been flat for more than a year. The fiscal outlook is definitely improving.

Chart #13

Our national debt is just shy of 100% of GDP ($31 trillion), but we are not on the brink of a fiscal abyss. On the contrary, it is not unreasonable to think that Congress can manage some degree of spending control, and it is not the case that the economy faces a crushing burden of debt in any event, as Chart #13 shows.

The true burden of debt is not the size of our national debt, but the cost of servicing that debt as a percent of our national income. Today that burden is significantly less than it was during the 1980s, mainly because interest rates are far lower than they were back then.

If Congress exercises even modest restraint and the Fed doesn't have to raise interest rates (which they won't have to if inflation remains under control), then we can gradually reduce our deficits and the burden of our debt. All things considered, things don't look so bad at all!

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Ionis Pharmaceuticals: Digesting Recent Events
data.description:
Shares of antisense therapy concern Ionis Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (IONS) have rallied strongly since its familial chylomicronemia syndrome med Tryngolza (olezarsen) bore strong data treating severe hypertriglyceridemia. Announced in September 2025, the results suggest it will be the new standard of care for the indication, prompting management to raise its peak revenue estimate by $1 billion to >$2 billion. The stock fell five percent in trading Wednesday after the company posted Q4 numbers. Management repeated its guidance for peak sales for Tryngolza following fourth quarter results.

With a portfolio yielding potentially >$4 billion in peak annual product revenue, >$2 billion in peak royalties, and >$6 billion in remaining milestones, the five-month run in Ionis merited a deeper dive. An analysis follows below.

Company Overview:

Ionis Pharmaceuticals, Inc., is a Carlsbad, California-based commercial-stage biotechnology concern focused on the development and marketing of RNA-based and gene editing therapies primarily for the treatment of cardiometabolic and neurological diseases. The company currently has seven approved and marketed products (five of which are out-licensed) and is advancing 11 late-stage clinical programs. Ionis was formed in 1989 and went public in 1991, with its first trade transacted at $10.75 a share. Its stock trades around $81.00 a share, translating to an approximate market cap of just north of $13 billion.

Products

Many of the company’s products and clinical programs are antisense therapies, which entail the creation of short, non-coded synthetic strands of DNA (antisense oligonucleotides) that are capable of binding to messenger RNA to influence gene expression.

Tryngolza. Of its seven marketed products, the first one that the company is selling on its own in its 37-year history and most germane to the its future success is Tryngolza (olezarsen), a once monthly, self-administered, subcutaneously injected ligand-conjugated antisense (LICA) therapy as an adjunct to diet to reduce triglycerides in adults with familial chylomicronemia syndrome (FCS), a rare, genetic disease caused by impaired function of the lipoprotein lipase enzyme, prompting extremely elevated triglycerides (10 to 100 times normal). Designed to lower triglycerides by reducing the body’s production of protein APOC-3, Tryngolza is anticipated to also receive approval for severe hypertriglyceridemia (sHTG), a condition characterized by triglyceride levels above 500 mg/dL, which is associated with potentially fatal acute pancreatitis (AP – sudden inflammation of the pancreas). In two Phase 3 studies (CORE, CORE2), olezarsen demonstrated placebo-adjusted triglyceride level reductions of 55% and 72% at six months (both p<0.001) and pooled data showed an 85% lowering of AP events after a year on therapy (p<0.001). Furthermore, 54% of patients on high dose (80mg) olezarsen achieved normal triglyceride levels (<150 mg/dL).

Those results should make Tryngolza the new standard of care for sHTG upon approval, likely forthcoming in 2H26. The market recognized these data when they were announced in early September 2025, rallying shares of IONS 35% to $57.49 in the subsequent trading session. Already off to an excellent start treating FCS (domestic population of ~3,000) with sales of $105 million during its first year on the market and patent protected until 2034, management now believes its triglyceride-lowering therapy should generate peak sales north of $2 billion, up from >$1 billion prior to its results against sHTG, an indication with a population of approximately three million Americans. For sHTG, active agent olezarsen has received Breakthrough Therapy designation from the FDA.

It should be noted that Arrowhead Pharmaceuticals (ARWR) received approval for its RNA interference therapy Redemplo (plozasiran) treating FCS in November 2025 and is evaluating it in a pivotal trial (SHASTA-3) for the treatment of sHTG, which should readout in 3Q26. Also pursuing this indication in the clinic are 89bio’s FGF21 analog pegozafermin (Phase 3) and NorthSea Therapeutics’ oral CETP inhibitor NST-1024 (Phase 2).

Dawnzera. Ionis’ other recently approved therapy is Dawnzera (donidalorsen), a once-monthly subcutaneous injection of prekallikrein-directed antisense oligonucleotide that was sanctioned by the FDA for prophylaxis to prevent attacks of hereditary angioedema [HAE] in patients 12 years or older in August 2025 and on January 21, 2026 in the EU. HAE is a rare, chronic, and potentially life-threatening condition caused by deficiency or dysfunction of the C1 inhibitor protein. It is characterized by recurrent attacks of severe swelling, typically in the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and airway, afflicting ~7,000 Americans. Approval was secured after Dawnzera reduced the HAE attack rate by 81% compared to placebo over 24 weeks. With three-quarters of patients currently treated with long-term prophylaxes and 90% interested in a new approach, management envisions peak annual sales potential for its HAE treatment at more than $500 million. Offering the potential for greater efficacy, tolerability, and convenience, Dawnzera enters a ~$5.9 billion global treatment market (Modor Intelligence – 2025) with five other approved therapies, including CSL Behring’s (CSLLY) recently approved anti-factor XIIa monoclonal antibody Andembry (garadacimab).

Out-Licensed Products

In addition to these two wholly owned commercial assets, Ionis has five other products that generate royalty or distribution revenue, the two most noteworthy of which are Biogen’s (BIIB) spinal muscular dystrophy med Spinraza (nusinersen) and AstraZeneca’s (AZN) Wainua (eplontersen). Spinraza was approved in 2016 and has generated royalty revenue between $200 million and $250 million since FY22 after peaking at $293.0 million in FY19. Wainua was approved for polyneuropathy of hereditary transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis (ATTRv-PN) in 2023, generating royalty revenue of $33.1 million in the first nine months of 2025 (YTD25). More importantly, it is under Phase 3 evaluation (CARDIO-TTRansform) for ATTR-CM (cardiomyopathy), a patient population of 300K to 500K worldwide (versus 10K to 40K globally for ATTRv-PN), and an ~$8 billion domestic market. Data on 1,400+ patients from the pivotal trial are anticipated in 2H26. Between the two indications, Ionis's co-development deal with AstraZeneca makes it eligible to receive up to $3.3 billion in milestone payments in addition to mid-20% royalties.

Pipeline

Zilganersen. Competition won’t be an issue if Ionis receives approval for zilganersen, an RNA-targeted therapy designed to inhibit the production of glial fibrillary acidic protein for the treatment of Alexander disease (AxD). The progressive and ultimately fatal ultra-rare condition that affects the brain’s white matter is characterized by a loss of muscle control and death within 14 to 25 years post symptom onset. After achieving its primary endpoint of change in 10-meter walk time versus placebo (p=0.0412), Ionis anticipates filing an NDA in 1Q26. Zilganersen has received Orphan Drug designations from the FDA and EU, as well as Fast Track and Breakthrough Therapy designations in the U.S. Management places its peak sales potential at north of $100 million.

ION582. Another wholly owned neurological candidate of note is ION582, a once-every-12-week RNA-targeted therapy designed to inhibit UBE3A antisense transcript expression, thus increasing the production of UBE3A protein for the treatment of Angelman syndrome, a disease characterized by intellectual disability, balance issues, motor impairment, and seizures that present at infancy. Afflicting ~100,000 in major geographies, there are currently no approved disease-modifying therapies. After demonstrating a 97% response rate as defined by the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development-4 (Bayley-4) at 18 months in a Phase 1/2 trial (HALOS), ION582 is undergoing evaluation in a 158-patient Phase 3 study (REVEAL) with the primary endpoint change in performance of the expressive communication subdomain raw score of Bayley-4. If eventually approved for Angelman, management believes ION582 can achieve blockbuster status.

Out-Licensed and Share Pipeline

In addition to zilganersen, ION582, and five other wholly owned clinical programs, Ionis has 12 out-licensed assets that are undergoing clinical evaluation, not including the aforementioned Wainua. The most advanced candidates are GlaxoSmithKline’s (GSK) chronic hepatitis B med bepirovirsen, for which a 1Q26 filing is anticipated, and Novartis’ (NVS) elevated lipoprotein(a)-driven cardiovascular disease treatment pelacarsen, which could launch in 2027. Between these two candidates and Wainua in ATTR-CM, Ionis projects peak annual royalty revenue of more than $1.6 billion.

3Q25 Financials & Revised Outlook

Owing to the fact that it is still early days for wholly owned products Tryngolza and Dawnzera, the company is not near breaking even as it advances eight clinical programs, including its co-development deal for Wainua. That said, management believes it will achieve cash-flow breakeven in 2028. That outlook was provided as part of its 3Q25 financial report on October 29, 2025, when it posted a loss of $0.61 per share (non-GAAP) on revenue of $156.7 million versus a loss of $0.72 per share on revenue of $133.8 million in 3Q24.

The top line was $26.5 million better than expectations, prompting Ionis to raise its FY25 revenue outlook by $50 million to $887.5 million, based on range midpoints.

4Q25 Financials:

Ionis Pharmaceuticals posted its fourth-quarter results Wednesday. The company posted a GAAP loss of $1.41 a share, which was nine cents a share short of expectations. For FY2025, the company posted an operating loss of just under $250 million.

Tryngolza posted $50 million of net sales in the quarter, up 56% sequentially from the third quarter. The product did $108 million in sales in FY2025, its first year on the market. Dawnzera did $7 million in sales in its first full quarter on the market. Spinraza had global sales of $356 million in Q4, generating royalty revenue of $54 million for Ionis. This was down from $64 million in the same period a year ago. Overall, royalty revenue came in at $76 million, down $1 million from 4Q2024. Commercial revenues (not including various milestones/other payments) rose 49% to $436 million in the 2025 fiscal year. Management offered its initial FY2026 guidance.

Balance Sheet & Analyst Commentary:

Ionis Pharmaceuticals ended FY2025 with roughly $2.7 billion of cash and marketable securities on its balance sheet. The company has not posted its 10-K for FY2025 yet but listed roughly $1.2 billion of convertible senior notes on its 10-Q following third quarter results. It appears over $400 million of 2026 notes were extinguished via a recent refinancing.

Several analyst firms (above) have slightly boosted their price targets on IONS following Q4 results, even as views remain somewhat mixed. On average, they expect the company to achieve profitability in FY28, when it earns $1.90 on revenue of $1.88 billion. The bottom line should accelerate rapidly from there, with Ionis generating $8.79 per share on revenue of $4.04 billion in FY31.

Verdict:

With two wholly owned products, five (essentially) out-licensed products, seven wholly owned clinical programs, 11 out-licensed clinical programs, and one co-development program, Ionis is an extremely active concern. Management estimates that from these 26 opportunities, it possesses annual peak revenue potential greater than $4 billion—thanks in large measure to the Tryngolza data in sHTG—annual peak royalty potential greater than $2 billion, and potential milestones totaling north of $6 billion. That said, shares of IONS are up over 80% since data from Tryngolza in September 2025 compelled management to raise its peak revenue estimate by $1 billion.

Additionally, there are risks to the narrative—most notably, if once-monthly injectable Wainua cannot best oral offerings from Pfizer’s (PFE) Vyndamax (tafamidis) or BridgeBio’s (BBIO) recently approved Attruby (Acoramidis) or Alnylam’s (ANLY) injectable RNA interference therapy Amvuttra (vutrisiran) in CARDIO-TTRansform. Furthermore, data from a Phase 3 study could compel partner AstraZeneca to prioritize its wholly owned IgG1-targeting monoclonal antibody ALXN2220 over Wainua for ATTR-CM. Lastly, Intellia (NTLA) and Regeneron’s (REGN) Phase 3 CRISPR therapeutic candidate NTLA-2001 could also alter the treatment landscape.

That said, even with the recent run and the potential risks to its story, its vast wholly owned and partnered pipeline of opportunities—as well as de-risked upside for Tryngolza—should allow shares of IONS to continue their grind higher over time. After its big rally, IONS doesn't merit a large position. However, when partnered with solid premiums in its options, Ionis is a decent covered call candidate. That is my way of saying, I don't mind accumulating a stake in IONS. I just want to do so at a lower entry point after the shares recent rally.
